headline: Fantastic company
pros: Accommodating, training and growth are big. If you take your development serious it is a good company to be at.
cons: Networking is key. Must network to have good career development.

headline: Tough job, Great Opportunities
pros: Great training and benefits. Leadership cares about associates. D and I focused.
cons: Very metric driven. Customers can be rude and demanding.

headline: Great career-starting company
pros: Benefits including profit sharing and bonuses are great. The breadth of this company provides a great opportunity to try out different career paths or boost your current one.
cons: In my current role, I am working overtime more often than I'd like with recognition that seems to only go so far until it sizzles out. That may be tied to the size of the company itself, where promotions work in a "trickle down" manner.

headline: Grow career and skills - then proactively leave
pros:
Profit sharing is the best in industry - you need to stay 5 years to keep it
Career growth and training is excellent - as long as you know the right people
Tuition reimbursement is excellent
Remote work is very nice
cons:
Read "Think Again" by Adam Grant - Fidelity is one of those companies that does not encourage thinking outside the box. 
Being wrong is not a virtue, nor is humility. 
Egoism thrives at Fidelity. 
Not a safe place for questioning the status quo. 
Do not criticize the process. 
Its all about who you know and not what you know.
Skills development is limited. Once you hit the limit, hit the door on your own and look for a company that encourages personal growth, otherwise you might get stuck in your role with no relevant skills. 
This is a spreadsheet and numbers company, not a people company. 
Your experience is highly dependent on your manager, who likely did not even do your job.

headline: Good company with good people
pros: The benefits are good, the people are nice, and the company does try hard to take care of the employees. 7% 401k match dollar for dollar and full health care coverage on day one. 25 days of PTO for first year employees.
cons: A lot of people working from home so it is hard to get to know your coworkers. A lot of time on the phones, but I would say 95% of the clients are nice. You have to pass your Series 7 & 63 pretty quick, they let go a few coworkers for not passing on the first try.

headline: Great benefits not so great working environment
pros: benefits, bonuses, locations, peer expertise levels
cons: not a lot of upward mobility, hybrid agile work environment (can't quite get there), having a hard time competing for high-quality talent, revolving door remote work model

headline: Constant opportunity for development and growth for those who want it
pros:
Large, privately held firm with values that are reinforced at all levels of leadership. Career opportunities are ongoing and the vast majority of people at the firm will help you progress if you're willing to do the work.
Fidelity provides exceptional benefits with options based on personal needs and various family situations. While pay and bonus structures are sometimes criticized, being patient will pay off for those who are willing to wait.
cons:
Fidelity retail is open 24 hours, causing scheduling conflicts for some candidates
Career tracks within the firm can be limited due to licensing requirements, or lack of licensing flexibility in the groups

headline: College Grads Beware, this is a call center
pros: benefits, beautiful campus, work life balance
cons: During the interview process, they change the wording to make it seem like it’s not a call center, but it is. We take calls back to back and follow a strict schedule. If we don’t follow the schedule, then we get yelled at by our managers. I was in a post grad rotation program and our managers basically treat us like kids. It’s pretty cringey and not professional. I felt like I was still in high school going through this program and I don’t really feel much growth. I didn’t go through college just to be stuck in a call center role, getting berated by customers on the daily. I felt like I was lied to during the interview process, because they market this opportunity in such a different way. Just tell us straight up that this is a call center and not waste anyone’s time. Majority of the roles within the company are call center positions, so there’s no way getting off the phones. The one thing I don’t understand about this company, is that the pay is so bad, but people are still so enthusiastic about their job, getting yelled at by customers and being “customer obsessed.”It gives off cultish vibes. Anyways, it takes a certain personality to really like being on the phones and following a strict schedule with a timed 30 minute lunch.

headline: Fantastic Employer !!
pros: The company and corporate culture at Fidelity is outstanding. I couldn't imagine a better environment where everyone wants to help each other learn, be successful, and experience different positions. If you are looking for a company that has a fantastic culture this is the company for you.
cons: There are a lot of acronyms used at Fidelity, and a lot of different titles that you will have to learn over time.

headline: Wonderful Place To Work
pros: Fidelity is very invested in the success of their employees.  Very collaborative environment with room to explore different career paths.
cons: Annual bonuses are based on stacked-ranking, which means even if everyone on your team is goes above and beyond or does the work of 2 people, almost all will get "meets expectations" and at least one or two exceptional employees will have to be in the "needs improvement" bucket.

headline: Wow! They call it financial Disneyland for a reason.
pros: Too many to list them all. The pay is good, extensive benefits, great training, fast promotions, and a contagious positivity! I have been around a decade in this business at 3 prior firms and none were half as good as fidelity. I am happy to sign on everyday and the relaxed dress code makes me feel comfortable! I could see myself retiring here and that says a lot since I’m 30 years away!
cons: Not one that I have seen thus far.

headline: Great place to launch career
pros: so many different types of accounting roles and easy segway into Finance roles
cons: morale, in the accounting department only, can be a bit dependent on your direct manager's attitudes

headline: Great Culture and Hours
pros: CRA is a great place to start and get your licenses. Lots of PTO and an easy job. Pays well for what it is.
cons: Boring. Many hours of dealing with incompetent elders who can't work a website. No way around using the website, so you are stuck helping them. Not that much room for upward mobility. Stuck at the same role for at minimum 1 year, per contract.

headline: Good Culture, Low Compensation, Weak PTO
pros:
Work and life balance is very manageable
Your ability to move within the organization is very high
Generally, the benefits are quite respectable, if not good.
cons:
Very low take-home compensation in relation to competitors -- after I moved business units the number of people I talked to who took pay cuts to work at Fidelity was surprising. A variety of reasons for taking the pay cut mind you -- family moves, future opportunities at the firm, disliking their current employer that much, etc.

A very notable alert if you evaluate and offer is that the Paid Time Off is a shared pool between vacation and sick time. You are required to reserve days in case you get sick. If you use too much of either you then have to "purchase" additional time. I come from the tech world historically, and this was incredibly surprising. I am not alone in not recognizing that this was the case prior to joining the firm. I, and others, just assumed that PTO was vacation only.

headline: Overall a great place to start a career
pros: I always feel like I can reach out to any of my colleagues with assistance on a topic I'm not as knowledgeable on.
cons: Rigid way of doing things

headline: Great Company
pros: Awesome work culture! Great company all around.
cons: Licensing can be a bit of a hassle.

headline: Loved it
pros: Great team great experience and an awesome program
cons: Nothing it was a great experience for me!

headline: Really great company if you do your time.
pros:
Very robust benefit package
-PTO
-Family/adoption benefits
-Tuition reimbursement 
-Medical
Lots of opportunity for growth and development 
They’re investing a lot to stay competitive and it shows.
If you’re in your early 20s get in early and it will do a lot for you.
Generally speaking, there is a lot of good leadership.
cons:
Base pay is relatively low for middle management/Sr individual contributor roles compared to other employers. This can make it hard to retain good talent. 

Some managers are incompetent. This serves to the detriment of the team and their goals. 

Bit of an old company but they are going to great lengths to modernize.

headline: Not what you think
pros: Company will provide additional supplemental income like retention bonuses because they know the job is tough
cons:
Took this job straight out of college thinking I’d be able to move up quickly. But pretty much anything you’ll move into will be another phone role. If you’re looking to move into leadership, don’t bother, they look for mostly outside experience which I literally heard from the mouth of one of the higher-ups. 
Call center work, boring, monotonous, mind-numbing, especially if you WFH and take back-to-back calls for 8 hours a day. I found myself being cursed out, threatened, called incompetent, a criminal, etc by clients which only made it worse

headline: Good experience
pros: Good work life balance, training and benefits.
cons: Customer service with constant customer interactions.

headline: NOT THE PLACE TO WORK IF YOU ARE A SINGLE PARENT
pros: Decent pay and sponsorship for licensing.
cons:
Lack of consideration for single parents who work from home with children. 
If you upset management in any way they will turn their back on you. 
Management should be more considerate and truthful. 
If you use your PTO too soon, but dont go over your limit, they will look to terminate you. 
If you fail the exam one time they will terminate you. 
If you have to take care of your child they will terminate you. 
You put in so much effort and time to study for the Series 7 and if you fail they will look at you badly. 
All in all, if you have a child and are a single parent and think Fidelity will understand if you have to help your child....they WILL NOT and will terminate you if you are a great employee who does their job well.

headline: Great place
pros: Learning Tuesdays are super useful for professional growth
cons: The agile transformation has been painful exclusively due to the scrum masters

headline: Glorified call center role
pros:
- Benefits
- 5k employee appreciation pay for all FT employees, regardless of length of employment
cons: Don’t be fooled - this role is literally just working at a call center, but the job description is very vague, and they are very deceptive throughout the interview process in order to make this role seem like more than it is. The first rotation was okay because you got to work in other roles and it wasn’t just a call center position, but in the second rotation, the managers and leads begin to micromanage you and treat you like you’re a child + you’re just taking calls all day every day.. Steer clear of this job if you’re looking for a position that’s not a call center role and will provide you with upward mobility.

headline: Fidelity is a place to work hard, get paid well and enjoy a longterm career.
pros: 7% 401k match, 10% profit sharing. They will pay for licenses (series 7, 66, etc) and other designation, such as CFP.
cons: Long vesting periods - a career company, it pays off but be willing to stick around!

headline: Fidelity
pros: Great culture, does not feel like you’re working in a big corp setting. Extremely accommodating during the pandemic. Private company and ignores the trends of other companies in the industry.
cons: No motivation to continue education or certifications, everything must be done outside of work if you’re looking for a new skill

headline: Great Company
pros: Values employees, strong benefits, high company morale
cons: Extreme oversight, political in nature

headline: Great to Employees
pros: Fidelity is great to it's employees and benefits are outstanding. They match 100% of the first 7% in your 401k, give everyone 10% profit sharing, and most people get annual bonuses. It's also hard to get fired. There seem to be quite a few inept managers that do very little and keep their jobs.
cons: On average, the pay is lower than the competition but I think that's why they make up for it with benefits. A lot of bad managers that get passed around but never fired.

headline: Stuck on Java
pros:
* More than enough PTO (23 days + 5 days covid/family relief time)
* Deadlines are reasonable for epics and sprints, low stress to get work done on time
* Pay is pretty good for RDU metro area
cons:
* Stuck on Java as the primary language. Reasoning for that is legacy code integrates more easily, and they know they can hire for Java. But recent graduates like myself probably don't like using it as much as Python, Go, etc.
* Slow to lay out concrete details for return to office

headline: Great Company to work for.
pros: Great Benefits. Managers do care about you as a person and help with development.
cons: changing work schedule widely varies.

headline: Great Job, struggle to see making a career here
pros: Great Benefits and people, the company is doing well and they are trying desperately to retain employees
cons: Despite the company's success, year-end raises are only 2-3%. The only real way to get a raise is to move to a different role within the firm.

headline: could be great
pros:
easy to get in through customer service and phone role
decent pay to get out of other lower paying industry. 
decent benefits package 
upward mobility available
there are a lot of people who have been with the company for decades and love it.
cons:
self paced training which basically teaches you the bare minimum. 
a lot of trial and error, you learn by making mistakes everyday. 
a lot of research while having time constraints 
its a lot of work. and it can take anywhere from 3 months to a year to stop feeling like a ball of anxious mess, 
theres a certain level of fear mongering that is used to make sure you do the job like they want you too. probably not best if you already struggle with anxiety. it will definitely kick it up a notch... a couple notches. 
they calculate more stats than you can even think of. these stats will be thrown at you daily and you will be asked to explain every bit if its out of the desired window. bonuses and pay increases depend on that. 
if any of these feel like pros to you then it may be the right fit for you.

headline: Great Culture and benefits
pros:
Great benefits
Amazing company culture
Lots of support from direct managers
cons: Too difficult to move up

headline: Great Company tons of stability
pros: Fidelity is a very sound and stable company.
cons: Can be hard to feel creative in a corporate driven environment

headline: Great company to work for
pros: great benefits, want employees to grow and develop
cons: some of the internal technology systems could use an update

headline: Great employer, but high expectations
pros: good benefits, 7% match + 10% profit sharing, generous OT and bonus potential
cons: phone roles are pretty tightly observed and burdened by a lot of different metrics -- it can be hard to succeed with so many competing definitions of success.

headline: Great place to launch career in finance.
pros: Great networking options, and LOTS of benefits. If you want to get into mostly any role this is the best place to start and they WANT you to move on and grow into the organization. Great job for newly graduated people.
cons: Not many, but the job itself is not the most fun.

headline: Great company with awesome benefits and friendly coworkers
pros: Great benefits, enjoyable coworkers and leadership, tons of fun and different technologies to work on
cons: Leadership seems overly focused on returning to office. Salaries could be more competitive

headline: Rewards newest employees and forgets the loyal employees who have been with the company for years
pros: Most benefits are very helpful for many employees e.g. student loan payment assistance, health insurance, etc.
cons:
They continually reward front line associates and upper management and associates in the middle are forgotten

If you’re in a middle-grade job, even if you’re a top performer and in a money-producing role for the company get ready to be disappointed about raises annually, whereas front-line associates receive multiple lucrative benefits (more bonuses, stock plan benefits, etc) to the point where they are making more than company veterans

Top performers in sales did not get a raise, nor large bonuses, and all the while front line associates are being rewarded MORE!

headline: Amazing company to work
pros: Good work environment, Good bonus
cons: Employes need to do interviews to be promoted even if the promotion is to the same team.

headline: Great job
pros: The pay is good, and benefits are better
cons: The work itself could become tiresome and there is burnout

headline: Excellent company with incredible benefits & work-life balance
pros: Work-life balance, total benefits package, culture
cons: Can be slow to change and adopt new processes

headline: Good if you need stability
pros: Things move at a pace that is fast but so fast that you feel overwhelmed. If you need a place to start your career that nudges you forward until you can really take off, this is a great place to work. People with a lot of experience out of the gate coming out of college might feel this is too slow-paced for them but it is still a good place to work for stability.
cons: New ideas are slow to be incorporated on the technology side of the company. If you want to work on the cutting-edge of tech, this is not the place that will offer you that. Big finance companies don't change tech until there are certainties.

headline: Fidelity Will Ruin Your IT Career With a Smile
pros: The benefits package is above average.
cons:
Fidelity will destroy an IT carrier.  

They will work you to death on out date tech that won't do you any good outside their doors.  

Manager's are immune to repercussions for their actions. While employees are expected to follow very high standards of conduct.  Discrimination of all forms is common and well accepted by HR.

If you are going to work for Fidelity make sure you fall into a category of person your manager likes, or they will destroy you with the full support of the HR department. 

You also better make sure you don't have kids to take care of, or turn 40.  I worked there for a decade and no one ever retired by choice.

headline: Awesome Company
pros:
-Very secure
-Smart People
-Incredible Opportunity Set
cons: Can be a political environment...

headline: Why Fidelity is best
pros:
Great work environment 
Great team support 
Fantastic benefits
cons:
Far from where I live
Only WFH for the time being

headline: Workplace Planning Consultant
pros: Student loan payments, Pay for professional licenses
cons: Delayed Bonuses, the bonuses are used to keep you with the company. Base pay isn't best.

headline: Best place I've ever worked
pros: Benefits, pay, schedule, culture, management are head and shoulders above any other financial firm I have worked for in the past. The job is incredibly reasonable and the pay is significantly above competition. If you can get a job offer from fidelity and you are working for another BD just take it. Upward mobility is real and they push it. If you are happy in your role you can stay in it without absurd changes in metrics. The company is solely customer centric so if you make a suggestion that makes the life of the client better that comes before profits.
cons: I work fully remote so you do miss some human interaction but that is a downside of any fully remote job.

headline: Great firm!
pros: Forward looking firm with solid fundamentals and a winner in its market segment
cons: A stronger culture would help

headline: Care about employees
pros: Great benefits and career paths
cons: Very few cons, great place to work.

headline: Great to work for
pros: Good company to work for, competitive pay and great benefits
cons: Will work you very hard.

headline: Great Company
pros:
Great atmosphere
Great Company 
Great Co-Workers
cons: There are no cons to working at Fidelity in my opinion

headline: Great Company
pros: Great Company to work for.
cons: No cons to add to this review.

headline: World Class
pros: Benefits are outstanding and opportunities for growth are plentiful.
cons: There really are not any major cons.

headline: Great Place to Learn the Industry!
pros:
-Management was great and went out of their way to help others succeed.
-GREAT benefits
cons:
-The employee interface needs to be improved. There are so many tech platforms these day that would benefit this business to simplify platforms and condense everything into one place. 
- The growth aspect wasn't appealing. The salary difference between the Financial Rep and Relationship Manager positions was not enough to keep employees motivated.

headline: AWESOME
pros: great incentives, awesome leaders, and fulfilling pay
cons: Passing the series 7 can be difficult

headline: Great Company That Really Cares About Its Employees
pros: Great working environment, great retirement plan, amazing people, interesting work, lots of mobility possibilities
cons: It's a large company so there's a lot of corperate jargen and intiatives that you have to deal with but it's pretty managable considering

headline: Lots of opportunities for networkers
pros:
Big company means lots of job movement possibilities
Quarterly/Semi-Annual/Annual Bonuses
Profit Sharing
7% 401k Match (5 year vest)
HSA compatible Health Insurance available
Lots of employee resource groups
Tuition reimbursement
Student Loan Assistance
16 week Maternity Leave/12 week Paternity Leave
Pet Insurance
cons:
Big company means you can get lost in the shuffle if you're not careful
Since there are so many other benefits, base salaries are on the lower end of the industry (you have to make sure you get the most value out of your benefits)

headline: great place to start
pros: stable job and career and good culture
cons: pay is not great compare with other companies

headline: Review
pros: Great people, pay and benefits.
cons: Don't have many cons as of right now.

headline: Great
pros: Training is so so great
cons: Stress is very very highp

headline: ISR
pros: Culture , benefits and upward mobility to work in a destination role or gain experience in different roles throughout this amazing organization.
cons: My role specifically is more of a generalist role so if your looking to learn a little about a lot of different aspects of Investment and Retirement planning it’s ideal. Thought I would be providing more planning and guidance than service and or support.

headline: Great company and benefits
pros: Great company with amazing benefits and extremely flexible
cons: Some managers can micromanage which is a huge con in a job position where micromanaging need not be.

headline: Great place to work, just wish they'd embrace full-time remote workers
pros: great benefits (student loan debt payback, over 6 weeks of PTO after 5 years, extra relief time for covid related incidents, 7% company match, profiting sharing, free managed 401k)
cons: Slow to adopt fulltime remote work. Even though we were at our most productive during the pandemic, management still thinks being in office is necessary.

headline: Great place to learn and grow
pros:
Good work life balance
Lots of opportunities for learning/developing new skills
Great benefits
Friendly culture
Some very talented people
Very successful company, feels good to be on the winning team
cons:
Lots of not talented people filling up seats
Org structure sets teams up for lots of duplicative and/or useless projects
Over emphasis on using specific tools for reasons other than enhancing the developer experience

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Great work life balance
Flexibility
Cares about employees
cons: Priorities and goals are sometimes unclear

headline: Role isn’t ideal, company is
pros: Wouldn’t want to be a part of any other company. Management, benefits, opportunities all top tier.
cons: CRA role after 6 months of training is phone role from clock in to clock out

headline: Good starter company or to retire at - bad for mid-career pay
pros:
Good culture and work-life balance
Decent benefits
Work on a lot of different technologies as full-stack developer
cons:
Base-pay is low for developers.. Expect 3-4 years to break 100k base salary.
Stock Trading restrictions - you have to wait 60 days to sell a stock after buying..

headline: Wonderful company
pros: Diversity and inclusion, cares about all employees, lots of career advancement opportunities.
cons: Unfair benefits as it varies by site and Albuquerque gets left behind other sites.

headline: Great
pros: Everything was great. Great place to work
cons: There were no cons. Everything was great

headline: Amazing company
pros: Unlike any company I have worked for before. Truly value there employees. No
cons: Great company nothing negative to list.

headline: Great Private Company
pros:
Private company that is customer obsessed but cares about it’s employees. 
You are encouraged to learn and grow, try new things, lots of career opportunities from financial to technology.
Awesome benefits.
cons: Always changing and evolving, initiative s are worked on and just as it is implemented, the compqny decides to move to a different direction.

headline: 401k team
pros: great benefits and extensive training
cons: None that I have faced so far

headline: Supportive, positive, professional company
pros: Great company, great culture, great benefits. Incredibly positive and professional. Very win-win-win oriented, everything seems to be done with the philosophy that benefitting the customer and employee benefits the company. Very positive mind frame to be working from.
cons: I haven’t explored outside the company in 15 years because the company makes it easy to want to stay.

headline: 20+ years at this great company!
pros: Fidelity has it all: flexibility, great benefits, diversity & inclusion, remote working options and good pay. We have a leader that cares about her (female owned, private company!) employees as well as the bottom line. During COVID, we were one of the first companies to go fully remote in order to keep everyone safe and healthy. I cannot say enough good things about Fidelity, and my tenure at the firm proves that!
cons: Some of the most improved benefits are for millennials. Not as many 'special' benefits for the 35+ age group. Raises are cost of labor not cost of living. Yes, there's a difference.

headline: It’s all about the metrics
pros: Nice people, good training, good benefits
cons: No matter how much they romanticize making a connection with clients, what truly matters in this role always comes back to metrics. If they can’t measure it, it doesn’t count, and you’re only as good as your metrics say. It’s relentless and offers little autonomy and a ton of scrutiny and micromanagement. If that’s not your thing, this isn’t your place.

headline: Awesome place to work
pros: Great perks, environment, pay is great, career growth is awesome
cons: More training for WPC I is needed

headline: Great company
pros: Nice encouragement and great opportunity at work
cons: Need to think about it

headline: Quality
pros: Great people and benefits. Huge advantages of being a private company and not chasing quarterly earnings.
cons: Very bureaucratic and management does not appreciate honest feedback - just wants you to get in line.

headline: Great Company and Even Better Benefits
pros:
-Great management
-Privately held
-Incredible retirement benefits (7% 401k match + 10% profit sharing)
-Endless avenues for career growth
cons: -Competition for Investor Center roles

headline: Launch Program=Call Center
pros:
-Decent pay $21.63 an hour
-Moving stipend up to 5k
-Appreciation pay (bonus) 5k even only being employed for 3 months 
-Benefits are great, health vision, student loan assistance
-opportunities to network virtually
cons:
-they market this program as a career move for recent college graduates where you get to learn different facets of the company. In reality it is just a call center. You are a customer service representative. After the 14 month program you are eligible to apply for different positions, if there are none available you stay on the phones. The phones are demoralizing and repetitive. This is a call center role. YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED.
-thousands of zoom calls very pointless
-moving to other departments outside of the call center can be difficult and met with a lot of resistance. You will often hear you have to “pay your dues” before you pursue a career aligned with your degree

headline: Awesome culture
pros: Fidelity is very mindful of the associate experience and I can’t see a world where I would want to work anywhere else. On numerous occasions Fidelity has been there for my family, and also the first workplace that helps me make sure I prioritize my family.
cons: Visibility into the different layers and jobs available under the Fidelity umbrella is not always equal across their regional sites. I was only able to get the job I was always looking for about 6 years into my career when I moved to their massive Texas location. I wish I had direct visibility In these roles so I can build my development plan accordingly.

headline: A truly great company
pros: They afford you the opportunity to broaden your horizons and prepare you for the necessary FINRA exams.
cons: The training is rough and not everyone makes it through.

headline: Fidelity values its employees
pros:
* Inclusive culture
* Beautiful campuses
* Values employees (they were willing to locate and provide accommodations for Texas associates and their families who lost power/water when the state froze over for a week)
cons:
* One size fits all mentality for computers (one of two reasons for the missing star)
* Lack of understanding the needs of test environments in agile development (one of two reasons for the missing star)
* Communication between “tribes”/products

headline: Solid Company
pros: Many avenues for future career development
cons: Starting from the bottom has slow mobility upward at Fidelity

headline: Long term career growth
pros: I started out at fidelity 15 years ago and throughout my tenure have been given opportunities to learn, develop and grow in my career learning different aspects of fidelity’s businesses
cons: High work volumes and lower base salaries

headline: NA
pros: Best in culture and diversity and internal mobility
cons: Many teams are hierarchy based

headline: Great place to work, solid benefits
pros: great benefits, people have long tenures,
cons: legacy company, can be reactionary

headline: Good company to work for, a few potential problem areas.
pros: Take very good care of their employees in terms of preparing them for retirement. Lots of smart, hard working people here.
cons: As in any large organization, there are pockets of good and bad. Work life balance was sorely lacking in my last role. Far too much work for far too few people, and nothing but more cuts on the horizon. Middle management re-organizes on every whim. Not much organizational stability.

headline: Avoid At All Costs:  Stuck In The Past - Beholden to Process and Refuses to See The Individual
pros: I encountered some very nice people
cons: The company is stuck in the past and refuses to see what is happening in the U.S. in regards to engaging employees as individuals instead of being so beholden to process and procedure.

headline: Okay company, lower pay than competitors
pros: Benefits are pretty solid, good systems to work in, never a lack of work
cons:
- Culture is awful, a bunch of fake people with no finance experience running a finance firm
- tough to take vacation
-overworked to the max

headline: Great company
pros:
Pto 
Heath care
Bonus
Monday through Friday
cons: Nothing I loved working remote

headline: Best Team culture
pros:
Best Team culture
Helping to grow skillset

headline: Fantastic place to work
pros:
Flexible work schedule,
WFH
Growth Opportunities
Great benefits
cons:
Repetitive job function
Start from bottom

headline: Toxic Atmosphere
pros: good benefits. great number of vacation days.
cons: Toxic Atmosphere bogged down by tenured reps. Regardless of who manages this group and what they do the group mentality always slips back into a caste system where the base level analyst are treated like second class citizens with no potential to grow. This job is unrewarding and you are graded only on what you have done in the last 24 hours. This is difficult as you are over worked and over tasked on a daily basis. Avoid this job. you can move laterally but upward growth is exclusively for external candidates.

headline: customer service
pros: professional , knowledgeable, great pay and benefits
cons: long days, long nights, customers ,

headline: Great place
pros: Great management, great investment opportunities for employees. Lots of opportunities to make commissions off of your sales based on your proactivity and perseverance.
cons: There's a big push for diversity at Fidelity Investments right now, so if you're not considered "diverse" then don't expect to get a promotion no matter how qualified you are.

headline: Under the Veil
pros: Learn Finance, Good starter Job, Updated Offices
cons:
Fidelity leaders grind their workers to no end (you will be burnt out quick). Plan on taking 70-100 calls a day.

No work/life balance. Fidelity preaches Work/Life Balance while also requiring you to work mandatory overtime the second you get licensed. 

Benefits are only good if you stay with firm long term (Schwab's 401k vest starting day 1, Fidelity requires you to stay for 5 year). 

Pay is lowest amongst other firms. 

You can be most talented candidate for promotion, but if you don't fit the firms "Diversity and Inclusion" efforts.... a less qualified or not qualified candidate will fill the promotion (If you are a white male good luck).

headline: Great company

headline: Stable benefits but some draw backs
pros: Their benefits are better than other companies with a 7% 401k match, up to 5 weeks paid vacation, and they throw perks like an extra week every 5th anniversary.
cons:
-They don't really hire women for high paying sales and financial planning. A woman can be CFP and they'll find other "salesy" roles where she is the face but they pretty much only hire men for all the high paying positions which are sales and upper management (except the owner, Abby). Women can get in on mid-and lower-management. They'll get support roles, help desk, etc.

-They offer stability and comfort. You work there for a long time bc they provide great insurance for the family and paid time off along with 401k benefits. Its not for the money.

headline: Good Benefits

headline: Great Benefots

headline: Fidelity Investments, great benefits, compensation but a fast pace no excuses work environment.
pros: Fidelity provides a very competitive compensation package but the benefits are best in the business. Benefits like a 7% 401k match plus 10% profit sharing is hard to beat. Medical benefits, loan repayment, PTO and the Charitable match are also unique.
cons: I worked at Fidelity for close to 20 years and the culture has shifted very dramatically to micro management, what have you done for me last week culture. In relationship roles your expected to produce unrealistic goals from existing client base while being compare to other reps receiving new clients with money in motion. Expectations presenting annuities is also concerning as a CERTIFIED FINANCIAL PLANNER. Too many good people leave sales and relationship roles to other roles in the organization due to burn out and which does impact the clients. FC roles are no longer a destination roles but rather a stop to some other role or outside the organization.

headline: 15+ years experience delivering enterprise solutions
pros:
great benefits (medical, dental, vision)
401k match up to 7%
profit sharing
bonuses
company shares
paid time off
discounts on mobile plan, car rentals, and hotels
education reimbursement
gym membership reimbursement
...
cons: salaries are a little below what others offer but they make it up in the benefits

headline: Remote Call Center work
pros: Benefits, Flexible hours, good pay with bonuses
cons: Strange hours, currently work from home which could be either a pro or con

headline: Benefits
pros: Great culture and people at the company!
cons: Can’t think of any cons

headline: Destination-Role or Your Stop
pros:
Company benefits
Highest general-service role achievable
6k+ Per quarter bonus potential (based on metrics: surveys & calls per hour)
Additional responsibilities like training and mentoring new associates
Great pay and competitive everything. Good PTO off the bat.
cons:
Fast paced environment
You still deal with bad clients (angry, confused), and sometimes get spillover from CRA like password resets
You are the first that calls go to, so the second you finish a call you’re guaranteed to get another. Good for CPH but it’s exhausting

headline: A great company
pros:
- Benefits are excellent.
- Very stable and low pressure job.
- Upper management genuinely seems to care. Employees frequently receive pulse surveys and then Fidelity will share the results from the surveys publicly, blemishes and all. You will actually see management try to make changes to fix the weak spots.
- A lot of focus on learning and development. 4 hours every two weeks is left open for any trainings, lessons, or experiments you are interested in doing.
cons:
- The base pay is lower than the market, making you reliant on your end of year bonus to bring it in line.
- Raises are low unless they come attached with a promotion.
- People tend to work at Fidelity for a very long time, which makes it difficult for new talent and ideas to come in and mix things up.
- Fidelity loves to pretend its a tech company, but does not have the technical talent to back it up. This causes there to be a lot of "flashy" things like containers and microservices, but not a lot of talent to utilize them fully which can make things worse than traditional architectures.

headline: Fidelity Senior Portfolio Specialist
pros: WFH, benefits, great coworkers, endless opportunities to increase investment knowledge, etc.
cons: None. Please refer to pros.

headline: Mixed Reviews
pros: Stable company, quick adjustment to remote work despite resisting it for years! Decent overall compensation though salaries are not competitive with industry and raises small or non-existent.
cons: Lousy low-level management. Dead-end phone service roles. A lot of hype around D&I while Abby's team remains mostly 'pale and male." Old-school mindset that in-office work culture is best. Despite great outcomes from remote work, management can't wait to get everyone back in-office when and if COVID-19 threat can be managed with reduced risk.

headline: Bitter & Sweet experience
pros:
Private nature of company gives it good flexibility. 

People are generally good.

Company has great brand.
cons:
Low Base Salary

The concensus based culture can kill innovation & slows things out significantly.

headline: Good company
pros: Great company, great management, great advancement opportunities, great benefits
cons: Not enough training time, overwhelming amount of info to know, hours aren't great, may have to work on christmas

headline: Hard work but rewarding
pros: I started working at fidelity remotely during the pandemic. They are very good about accommodating a flexible/ work from home environment, and there are currently lots of opportunities for mobility. I am always in awe of my hardworking and dedicated peers - there is a sense of pride in a job well done.
cons: The only bad thing thing about lots of mobility is lots of people moving around and extra work falling to the folks that are left. It can be very grueling sometimes. While the benefits are good, the starting wage is low considering how much you have to know to effectively do your job.

headline: Overall Excellent Company
pros:
Job security, Work-Life Balance, Great Benefits, From my experience excellent managers that work with you and do not add unnecessary stress

For many roles, you will have great job security and be extremely well-compensated compared to other companies in the industry doing the same role.

I will say that they do have a vested interest in taking care of their associates and I do feel more valued than I would in other big-name companies.
cons:
-Does not sponsor you for licensing unless you are in a role that requires it.

Overall most of the cons can be applied to any big corporate organization.

-Job growth and ability to be promoted within is definitely there, but I have seen some people become stuck in their roles if they stay too long or do not develop skills to move onto the next position. 
- In addition, moving up to management can take quite a while. I have seen it happen within the company, but a large number (especially an overwhelming number of upper-level management) either left the company and came back or were recruited externally. However, this is something that can be seen in almost any company you go to. 

- From the above my experience with management has been great, but I know on some high-intensity teams (such as sales or fund management) can have more stressful managers, but I have not heard anything terrible to note.
-Career center is just incapable

headline: Good place to work
pros: Benefits are great and it is a fairly flexible job. You learn a lot of great financial principles that will help you no matter where you go or work.
cons: Most jobs are call center jobs and no matter where you go you will get basic service calls. It is very politically correct environment and the internal company politics are very annoying (its all about who you know).

headline: I love my job
pros: Benefits are fantastic. Company listens to their employees. 401k match. Work life balance. Dynamic work environment (wfh/in office).
cons: Have to push through the phones. But SO worth it.

headline: Company Review
pros: Great benefits and great chance for advancement. You only need to be mediocre on your job and you will succeed. Change your position often. It is the best way to get pay increases and increase your value.
cons: Saw many associates do a terrible job and still get raises and promoted. You will get noticed after first raise then after that it has no bearing on your success. Last year working I was ranked high in my stats and still got no raise. Do not stay in one position for more than 3 years, your raises and value decrease.

headline: Unhealthy environment
pros: The people, the benefits are great
cons: The higher the leadership closest to the top, the more close minded and attached to old school culture they are, trying to force everyone into outdated thinking.  They will also lure you into new roles and lock you down without being honest about what the role really is.  You get “used” as a vessel to push upper leadership personal motivations and accolades, while slowly being quieted down and eventually silenced.  .  It’s just a bunch of senior leaders trying to outshine each other and get their name on something even if it’s not best for the employees.  Will get overwhelming associate feedback in surveys about wanting to work remote and will only tell you about the one comment from someone who wants to be in the office and then try to gaslight you into believing it’s the majority opinion.  Leadership will “threaten” that you’re luck the President is giving you any flexibility because she would prefer not to and force you to give up all of your flexibility if you don’t agree to work in the office sometimes.  Kind of like “ you’re lucky to get anything.  Don’t push your luck or she will take all your toys away.  The culture was going in an amazing direction the past couple of years.  But in a very short time it’s gone backwards and more toxic than it’s ever been.

headline: Great company

headline: well run company

headline: Poor Communication

headline: Awesome company!!
pros: I’ve been here for almost a year and waited until I had “seen it all” to post a review. Fidelity really cares for their employees, what they say is VERY true. We get bonuses on top of bonuses just by working and doing what we’re supposed to be doing. Amazing PTOs about 23 days for all associates that have been here for less than 2 years. Amazing health, dental, vision etc etc the standard basic benefits but what really got me was how much they invest in you as an associate. I’m truly blessed to work for such a great organization!
cons: Micromanaging can be a problem however, as to be expected if you are on a phone role. May feel like you are “stuck” and stagnant at a role but in the mean time I am seeing lots of employment opportunities to move around. It may take a bit longer for you to move around and the pay may be below average for the same job elsewhere but the benefits package are for sure to be top notch all around.

headline: Sane, humane, a little slow
pros: Fidelity treats people well, and depending on your manager, it’s very easy to have clear priorities, goals to reach for, and a dose of predictability. It can be a bit of a reorg factory, and like all huge enterprises, experience varies hugely across the org.
cons: Most of the company adjusts slowly to change. If you’ve got an “I want to see my work have impact right away” mind, you may be dismayed. But the caution, overall, is prudent and reflects conscious deliberation. If you can work at enterprise speed, it’s a good place, but you’ll lose your mind if you’re a sprinter.

headline: Older workers, beware
pros: Nice coworkers and good benefits
cons:
First of all, what's with all the 5 start reviews that are one line and the cons are "None that I can think of" and variations on that them?  If you removed all the suspicious cheerleader reviews, I wonder what the rating would be?

Salaries are within a range lower than competitors and there is little chance for promotion, especially if:

* You are in the wrong org. It's hard to get recognized in some roles, even if you excel.
* You are an older worker. After positive reviews, there are no rewards while younger coworkers within the same level and similar reviews get raises or shares.
* Crippling bureaucracy.
* Senior leaders set processes and then don't enforce them with other senior leaders.
* Fidelity is an "Agile" organization, except for senior management demanding delivery schedules 4 quarters into the future.

Instead of any sort of follow up or proactive reach out to me with warning, I was immediately fired with no questions. I loved this company and I loved my job, and I was good at it. I hate that one month cost me my entire career, and my manager did not try to reach out at all.

headline: Why didn't you refer this plan participant to a nearby Fidelity Investor Center?
pros: Financial planning tools are effective, if you slip up and actually provide real financial planning to the plan participant. Less than all of the participants are rude and ignorant. You'll always be able to ply your craft because there is always a queue of participants to speak to. The Fidelity RSP 401k match is strong and, coupled with 10 percent profit sharing, makes it very easy to save a lot of money for retirement. So you'll only be poor during your career and not also in a long retirement.
cons: Fidelity wants Workplace Planning and Advice and its Workplace Planning Consultants to refer opportunities to the Investor Center. That's the job. Say whatever you need to get the referral and you'll advance in your career. Any personal ethos of Do what's Right will be compromised in WPA. The answer to everything, everything, is refer the opportunity to the Investor Center. Also there is no way that compensation for Fidelity phone roles is materially-higher than any industry average.

headline: High stress
pros: Good pay and benefits are provided.
cons: Almost every metric imaginable is tracked. This is an extremely stressful work environment with no down time. The extra money I receive from this company is offset by medical expenses to manage my anxiety and depression I’ve developed since working here. You will be continually told that relief is coming in the form of more employees, but for three years this has yet to happen to counteract turnover. If you want to take 6-8 phone calls an hour, be insulted daily by clients, work mandatory overtime, and develop crippling mental health issues, this is the company for you.

headline: High Expectations are unrealistic
pros: Pay is good, hours are good.
cons: The time off request procedure and absenteeism policy is unrealistic for any human to adhere to. Example: Requests for approved time off must be sent in 2 weeks in advance, otherwise time off is an occurrence. If you request time off in the two week advance time period, despite being an emergency request, it may count as an occurrence because Fidelity decides that they will be busy in that day and forces you to take an occurrence if you dare keep your emergency time off that you needed for a doctor visit. This place is all about being an employee revolving door like most call centers. They claim to be family centered business but you will see in time that is not true. Specifically if you are a single parent, be prepared to be written up if you have to take 20 minutes to pick up a sick child from school.

headline: Unrelenting Work Environment
pros: Many very talented colleagues and depending on where you work you get to do very interesting work. Internal information and learning resources are great.
cons: A ceaseless grind. Nervous, risk-averse, fear driven work environment. Restructuring and layoffs were constant. Success is entirely in the hands of your direct manager, so while it depends on who your manager is, largely the culture reinforces doing what the boss says and being very cautious about expressing any alternate perspectives. Many people have been there for years and the inside club can be defensive of their turf. You are encouraged to not think of compensation and instead the 'total value' of the package, but never-the-less, I found overall pay to be below market.

headline: Great Company for the Ambitious and Energetic
pros:
Lots of pros! The pay, the perks, and the people are all great. Fidelity has tried really hard to support employees during COVID, through extra paid leave specifically coronavirus-related, counselor-finding services, fun activities and food provided for people who are willing to come back into the office part time during virus lulls.

Fidelity is also working hard on diversity-and-inclusion, and on making sure employees' voices are heard from the ground up. The company supports outside volunteer efforts and onsite environmental initiatives. You can feel good about working for a company that wants to do good, not just do well.
cons:
Most people are hired into Fidelity at this position. It's a pretty rigorous process, from submitting the application through multiple interviews. Once you're hired, there are two potential hurdles: first in learning the job then in doing the job.

Oh, the learning process! Even entirely online as it has been since the pandemic, it's kind of fun. There are get-to-know-you activities with your newbie group. But there is also a LOT of information to absorb, and it doesn't let up for months. First you learn the Fidelity systems, then you go through licensing training. You must pass the licensing exams to advance within the company. From hire, this all could take 4-6 months. Yes, they pay you the whole time. Once you're licensed, you alternate more Fidelity-specific classes with actual customer support for a few more months before you settle into full time on the phones. After a few more months of that, you may start applying within the company for new skills and new roles, your options being more self-directed.

So, the cons: the pace of learning is set to warp speed, be prepared! Realize that while you're learning you cost the company quite a bit. It's a lot of stress, but they'll want to push you as fast as they can get you to go. And once you're on the job, well, it depends. Some people like inbound phone customer service, or at least don't mind it. Fidelity customers are usually quite pleasant really. But especially in the busy months, from maybe November through tax season, they can spend more time on hold than they like, which makes them cranky. There will be constant pressure from Fidelity for you to make each call as brief as possible: they will measure both your customer satisfaction stats AND your calls per hour. It can be hard to balance the one against the other. And, this is the job: call after call after call. There are breaks, of course, from weekly team meetings to personal lunch and break time to refresher education. If you can continue in the inbound phones roles long enough, you can eventually get promoted out of it if you choose: perhaps 1-5 years, generally?

cons: Sometimes Fidelity's past success can be its biggest challenge. There can be some organizational silos and resistance to change and innovation. There's still a lot of legacy technology and many platforms where release cadence is too slow to be compatible with agile methodology. There are a lot of annual required trainings that are not relevant to my day-to-day job.

headline: Only dedicated need apply
pros: If you’ve got what it takes, this can be a great career. Beware, this is not meant to be a job that you only do for a year or less. Choose this job if you’re ready to commit to a career that is going to be very long-term, or even lifelong. The amount of effort, and commitment that you will need to put in during your extended training is the kind of commitment that will have you rearranging vital portions of your life if you wish to be successful. They will warn you ahead of time. He does warnings. They’re being serious. If, however, you can make it through all of this you’re going to have gainful employment at an excellent rate of compensation for the rest of your life. There are also a few employers who treat their people as well as Fidelity.
cons: The work can be incredibly difficult, and even mindnumbing. The extended training is grueling to say the least. While the support is there from Everyone around you, what the average person will need to give up for several months will be substantial. You will lose friends, you will upset your family, and you will likely encourage great amount of stress during this time. Licensing is very difficult time.

headline: Life Changing Career Decision
pros:
Excellent Training, Outstanding benefits, Healthy work/life balance. Amazing tuition reimbursement. Great place to launch a career or facilitate a career change. 
Jaw-dropping 401(k) match and profit sharing. Best career decision I ever made! I am eternally grateful for the impact Fidelity has on me and my family. Transparently, my financial future will be dramatically and positively different because of my career at Fidelity. Very proud to tell others where I work!
cons:
The only con I have is that Fidelity is more focused on hiring externally than promoting from within. Much of this focus is due to recent cultural and economic events (i.e., 2020). From a business perspective, I understand the desire to capitalize on available and diverse talent but not at the risk of frustrating and overlooking your highly qualified and tenured associates. There is a simmering frustration among the ranks and will soon result in sizable attrition if not addressed. 

For example, I am the most credential and skilled associate of my team and keep getting overlooked for a particular role. The individuals that are being hired into this role are under credentialed and/or have less experience. It is the most frustrating thing in the world! For the first time in my tenure at Fidelity, I have started proactively looking outside the firm. It genuinely PAINS me to think I may have to join a competitor to advance my career and compensation.

headline: Tech divisions lag the market in tooling, processes, comp, management, leadership, dev experience.
pros: The benefits packages are fully-featured and health insurance is affordable. The best perk of Fidelity is the 7% 401k match and the 10% annual profit sharing; 17% contributions to your 401k overall each year. The work/life balance ends up being very reasonable - it would be uncommon to work a 45-hour workweek more than a few times a year. 40 hours is the very common norm.
cons:
Fidelity does not use public cloud, which has many negative side-effects; they attempt to replicate that experience with older, internal tooling which dramatically slows developer velocity. For example, engineer's ability to access compute resources is blocked by request processes. Libraries are all subject to a security review which can take a small number of weeks if requested with priority, or many weeks without. Licenses are purchased by a remote requisitions team with a similarly slow resolution timeframe. Releases are produced manually, there is no continuous deployment. 

There is no universal devops/platform team, squads maintain their own services. 
This self-sufficiency produces isolation, practically and socially; process standards and tooling varies a fair amount between them. There is no architecture team or unified technical leadership group. Each squad has their own tech lead and that's it.

Pay for engineers lags the market, targeting approximately 80-100% of the market rate. There is no option to acquire equity. "Chairman shares" are offered to top performers, but those are simply 2-year vesting cash bonus - not actual equity. Anecdotally, the very talented engineers remain due to not knowing their own market value. 

The manager-to-report ratio can vary wildly, 50+:1 in some cases, offering virtually no manager facetime or development opportunities to members of those squads. The daily routine of managers and directors is primarily comprised of liaising with customers (other business units) rather than anything related to developing their engineering teams.

Because the tech groups service internal business units, customer requirements are often poorly defined, change frequently and are conveyed verbally to product managers over calls. Oftentimes a change will be reverted due to a customer's whim, not the functionality of the feature itself.

Leadership is adamant about working from the office and will not support remote work post-covid.

Leadership has frequent messaging about undergoing an agile transformation, yet none of the shortcomings described here are eligible for reevaluation. The remaining set of factors that can be changed are virtually meaningless in impact.

Talented top-level leadership want to lead other business units which are revenue centers (all are financial business units) rather than cost centers, so the tech groups end up with a steady rotation of SVPs (the head of the tech group, equivalent to a CEO elsewhere) every 1-2 years. 

In short, the engineer experience at Fidelity is stable, yet slow, uninspiring, and poorly-compensated when compared to the broader market.

headline: Depends on the role
pros: Benefits are really good. 401k match, profit sharing, health benefits. All great. Pretty generous PTO, especially after you have been there a while. The base pay is okay.
cons:
Fidelity can be great. It depends on two things: what department/role you are in, and your manager. My major complaint about WPC is that people who play the game and burn through calls get promoted and those who spend time with clients don’t. You are not encouraged to spend time and plan with a client. You are supposed to get your tool clicks, uncover assets and send a referral to a branch. It has developed a culture of work 12 hour days to get your numbers, or cut corners. 


Also, they required mandatory overtime on Monday’s and Friday’s for over 6 months. Demanding total flexibility from all reps and continually asking for more, more, more. But good luck using your PTO. Some managers will act like you are stealing PTO hours from their own bank when you ask. The “COVID relief days” they offered were total BS as well. Their policy stated you could use it for anything that required “flexibility” during the pandemic. However, most managers would only let you take it if you were sick COVID.

headline: Great company to work for!

cons: As is the case with all large organizations, sometimes it's hard to pinpoint the person or group incharge. Also, be prepared to learn the 'Fidelity' way; it can get a little frustrating to figure out how to build systems/integrations the way Fidelity wants it done. It took me about 6 months just to get enough internal knowledge to be really affective.

headline: Great Company! Why look anywhere else?!
pros:
-Respectful, Inclusive Workplace! Fidelity encourages anyone to bring up to someone you trust about something someone did or said that made you uncomfortable and Fidelity has no tolerance for inappropriate and disrespectful behavior! 

-Since COVID 19 hit 99% of this company works from home! (This position allowed working from home 2 days out of the week before COVID happened.)

-Work from home but not alone! Excellent technology giving you all the tools you need to be successful and feel connected with you coworkers and managers. 

-Flex time! With this position getting one planned paid hour off a week. ( i.e Getting off at 4 instead of 5 on Friday and getting paid that hour. What company does that? 

- VERY STABLE! When companies during COVID-19  are laying off people this company is hiring.  Most businesses get busy in the summer while this company gets busy in the winter.

-Free  Essential Health Insurance

- Job Advancement! The Career Center is dedicated in giving you resources for job advancement where the people associated are there to help you obtain a job you want within Fidelity. 

- Plenty of other Pros!
cons:
Call center work is repetitive. 
(You have to really fish for cons to find them with a great company like this)

cons:
- As a CRA my entire job was answering a nonstop stream of phone calls
- While the training program is nice, you will NEVER fully be trained or prepared for what calls you may receive. 
- There is a massive variety of calls you may receive, which can leave you juggling a client, researching a solution and reaching out to other departments to find a solution.
- Once training was done I was put onto a new work schedule that ruined my work/life balance. I tried for multiple months to get a new schedule but since I was a newer employee I was never able to get something a bit more accomodating.

headline: Not for those who want to be excited about a job or make a single connection in the workplace.
pros:
Very clear on corporate culture. 
Updates from superiors (CEO, etc.) multiple times a week.
Will pay for your licensing if you’re in a licensed role.
Pretty easy to get vacation days approved.
cons:
This is not a job for someone who can’t sit in the same chair, staring at the same computer screen for 8+ hours.
Working from home is miserable, but working in the office requires either weekly testing and tracking or the vaccine. 
I’ve never felt so lonely at a company, even though this is the biggest company I’ve ever worked for.
I barely even know my manager’s first name, that’s how disconnected everyone is.
I only lasted one month after I finished training because the job isn’t rewarding in the slightest.
Be prepared to get yelled at or called incompetent at least 5 times a day.
Don’t expect more than minimal support from any supervisor.
This position should pay much more than it actually does. 
During onboarding, they make it seem like you can move around as much as you want, as quickly as you want, and your manager will help you advance however they can, but that’s a joke.
By the end of my shift, I’m exhausted and can’t even build up the motivation to make dinner.
EVERYTHING is scheduled. You get two 15 minute breaks - one in the morning and one in the afternoon - and a 30 minute lunch, but you may not be eating lunch until hours after any normal lunch time should be scheduled. And you don’t get a say on that either.

Also, there is constant change with the call model which they eat, sleep, and breathe. You could be the worst employee and as long as you use their call model word for word youll be able to move up quickly. Its also at manager discretion if you hit your call or not. Overall? Lets be honest.... What finance job isnt soul sucking???

headline: Great place to start and grow your career
pros: I've had fantastic luck with every one of my managers. I heard this makes all the difference. My managers were amazing mentors and each provided an amazing perspective on how to work your way up to corporate ladder. Huge piece of advice, from the moment you start, think two steps ahead on where you want to go. Let your managers know and they'll help you get there.
cons: If you are passive, you'll be stuck in the same role for years. There are opportunities out there, you just need to look for them. I started in Customer service, and that first year was definitely the hardest. I knew nothing and felt incompetent. After a year, once you begin to build your knowledge base, you can actually have meaningful conversations so I'd say stick with it. Entry level jobs usually feel exhausting and difficult. Progress can sometimes feel slow, but I've never been in a role longer than a year and a half.

headline: Fantastic Workplace

headline: Best in the biz (its the biz thats the problem)
pros: Great benefits, good pay and great culture. Although limited and flawed at times the company does care and tries to help every associate succeed. Also a lot of upward and sideways mobility, if you work hard the world is your oyster. Also you gain SO MUCH important knowledge about economics and the stock market that you can use in everyday life.
cons:
Internal systems are a nightmare, its a Frankenstein mishmash of all these old in house systems that don't play nice together and are not very user friendly. Also training is rushed adding an un-needed degree of pressure to new hires already working a difficult job.

 And the job no matter how good everything else could be is a tough tough job. It takes at least a year to get any good but once you pass your "trial by fire" and give it 100% this can be a very rewarding career especially for someone like me with no college degree.

headline: Better than the service industry, but still service
pros:
Lots of assistance offered to get you licensed (SIE, series 7, series 63).
Inclusive culture is pushed (don't expect everyone to be that way, but at least they try to make it welcoming).
Better than minimum wage.
Opportunities for growth.
cons:
UNDERPAID! This role requires you to live within 100 miles of Fidelity, yet they do not pay enough for a person to afford to actually live by themselves near Fidelity which is absolutely shameful.
It is like being in a minimum wage job except with better pay (though, like I said, still underpaid). You get limited breaks, you are expected to clock in ten minutes early each day, it can be difficult to use your PTO. The customer's rate us on a 7 point scale, but the only acceptable score is 7 points. If you get rated a 6, that is considered failing.
This role is very challenging and directly customer facing. There is a lot of pressure because you are dealing with customer's money. Fidelity throws you right into it, I did not feel ready to be moving money for customer's on my own but you just gotta do it.
It is great that they sponsor you through the licensing process, but it is really easy to get burned out by their pace. Then, if you fail, prepare to be "let go."
It is a FINRA rule that licensed employees cannot work from home full time without an exception process that Fidelity is not interested in participating in (it would require them to inspect your home office so I can't blame them for not wanting to do that). We can WFH right now, but will be forced to go in at least part time once it is deemed safe.
Fidelity is really pushing for people to return to the office, lots of pressure to participate in "connect weeks" which is where you volunteer to go back to the office.
They send you a lot of free stuff but most of it is junk. Like cheapy backpacks/mugs/merch you didn't ask for. I am putting this as a con because even though it is nice to receive free things and in the moment it gets you feeling part of the group, this practice has to stop. It is not good for the planet to keep producing useless junk.

headline: Leadership is full of sycophants
pros:
* Job security
* No work pressures
* Internal movements
cons:
* About 60% staff is useless. You bump into people who call them leaders, managers, agile gurus, but have no clue about the product, or business, or technology. 
* Leaders are sycophants, who love sycophants. Hence only sycophants move up. 
* Promotions happen not based on merit. But sycophant leaders choosing their favorite sycophants 
* When leaders move to a different organization they take these incapable sycophants with them - they together spoil the culture of the new team
* Good people are leaving. Many great leaders who build core systems from ground up are not rewarded. Sycophants who have no knowledge of product, business, or technology are constantly repelling them 
* In the name of diversity & inclusion, incapable people are being promoted to the highest positions and they are failing everyday

headline: Best place to work
pros: This job and company really gives you a home life balance. The managing team is always pushing to find ways to help its employees not just in their work but lives as well. They take care of us so well I am always motivated to do my job.
cons: It can be mentally draining when a lot of people bombard you at once with complaints. At the end of the day you have to remember you are there to fix there problems.

headline: Changing for the worse
pros:
Benefits
Remote work
Great place to start your career. Get out and get paid more after.
cons: Have worked here for 6 years in 3 different locations. Management has gotten worse. I used to think “Wow. The management really cares about advancing my career and helping me” that tune has changed. It’s become a corporate boys club and full of toxic negativity. You have to leave the firm and come back to get any type of promotion or pay increase. They don’t hire from within they literally have jobs that say external hire only. What kind of garbage is that? It’s a boys club so if you’re a female in this finance world, good luck. Management is fake and can’t be real with their employees like they used to. They have to drink the corporate Kool-aid and give everyone corporate BS answers. Fidelity has started to care so much about money that the client experience is going to the way side. I used to love how client oriented we were. They are changing everything to be about money and how do we make the most money and work the employees the hardest.

headline: Great Place to Start
pros: If you have a business degree and not sure where to start - look no further. Fidelity really invests in you by literally paying you to study for the first 9 months. 2-3 of those months are for studying for the SIE, Series 7 and Series 63. The rest of the time is learning Fidelity's training and the way they do things. In this time you might have to take some calls but its fairly easy. There is a lot of room for career advancement. You most likely won't stay in a position for longer than a year without some type of promotion. I think its a great place to start off your career in the corporate world.
cons: Calls do suck after a while, but if you apply yourself you can get out of there pretty soon because Fidelity is hiring so many new people each year.

headline: Good benefits and pay but micromanaged
pros: Great pay and good benefits with 18 days PTO a year and a 7% 401K match. Monday-Friday schedule that stays consistent and optional OT. Potential to advance career.
cons: Micromanaged. It is a call center so stats are everything. If you are under preforming they will watch your every call and even listen in without you knowing. Also your bonus is mainly based on customer reviews but customers will use the review to complain about plan rules that you cannot control. So you will receive a lower bonus for simply doing your job, and stating the plan rules.

headline: Working at Fidelity Investments

cons: Management can have unrealistic expectations for its associates. Responsibilities can change on a daily basis which creates hectic environments.

headline: Management only cares about metrics and fails to look at bigger picture.
pros:
-401k match
-Tuition reimbursement
-decent work-life balance
-trauma bonds built with coworkers forged friendships that will last a lifetime
cons:
-Very political environment with lots of nepotism. This allowed many undeserving and incapable people to become management.

-True competence and hard work was noticed by managers, but rarely actually rewarded. Only numbers were considered important, and these metrics were easy to manipulate if the employees lacked integrity. If you wanted to succeed, you had to be prepared to cheat in one way or another.

-Complete lack of mobility between departments. Many employees joined the company because they were told that it was possible to transition to analyst work. When they became eligible to move departments, they were mysteriously kept in customer service (even if they worked very hard and networked well in order to be able to leave).

-Constant changes that made your job more difficult without any additional pay or thanks. This was a never ending flow of additional responsibilities handed to us.

I also do thing they pay very well according to me anyway. I am making the best money I have ever made.
IF YOURE LOOKING FOR A CAREER FOR YOU FAMILY OR EVEN JUST YOU, APPLY HERE!

headline: It is what you make it.
pros: This company is A+. The opportunity to grow is abundant, leadership (team managers) are excellent (all of mine have been). Fidelity is way ahead of the investing game, they have happy clients because they have happy employees. The sales route is competitive, but your success is based on merit and how much you contribute over how long you've been in role. You can really grow here if you are a positive individual who hustles.
cons: The internal software is the worst element of the job. Windows 98 level systems that are so large it's daunting to think about creating new systems. The learning curve for systems is a real sore spot which is being addressed; hopefully with all the focus it needs.

headline: It’s a marathon from sign on to sign off
pros: The company has great benefits…. lousy pay, but they try to make up for that with the benefits. They offer a 401k match and profit sharing too.
cons:
It’s a marathon! From when you sign on to when you sign off it’s call after call after call… and they monitor you on everything. 

To give you an idea on the difficulty of the job. A new higher class might consist of 20 people. By the time you factor in getting licensed, trained, and then on the phones and go out one year… the quit out rate will have been 75% that’s 3 quarters of a class. 
It’s a tough job and for those who apply and can make it good for you. I lasted five years and left once I was fully vested.

headline: Great Company but below market base compensation & stagnant raises

cons:
- Base pay is well below market competitors
- Raises each year are also below market
Note, to be fair, benefits like the 401k & Profit Sharing match make up for some of this difference but the total compensation package is looking less appealing each year vs. competitors.

headline: Bias work environment
pros: Amazing insurance and time off benefits , managers are great to work with, employees are nice and friendly
cons: My biggest con is around covid and others may see it as a plus. However, “equal opportunity employer” is not true. If you’re vaccinated, you get extra time off the phones, free lunches in the office, development opportunities not given to those not allowed to go into the office. Whether you have medical reasons or not to not get the vaccine. It doesn’t matter to them, you will be treated less than equal which does impact career development because you don’t have the same opportunities given to those who are vaccinated.

headline: Data scientists go elsewhere
pros: It pays well and the benefits are good.  There are women in leadership positions.  For tech people at least, fairly flexible.
cons:
Oh where to start.  I worked in Fidelity labs.

The so called culture of "speaking frankly" and "taking risks" is 100% a lie.  You can speak as frankly as you want as long as you're saying what your manager wants to hear.   You cannot innovate.  My manager incorrectly considered himself an expert in the fields of every person on his team and never accepted any opposing views.   All the data scientists on my team quit.  No one reached out to us.  Nobody cared.  Take this warning seriously.

headline: So many opportunities
pros:
•The benefits are the best I’ve ever been offered
•Career mobility opportunities 
•Amazing Networking opportunities 
•They care about their employees 
•They care about local communities

It has been really great to work for Fidelity. I started 5 years ago as a seasonal customer service rep, with a goal to stay on learn the systems from the front end and transition to tech. Fidelity paved the path to success for me. I worked hard got hired on full time and eventually utilized one of their amazing career mobility programs and was trained as a software developer. It is because Fidelity cares so much about building up their employees that I have been able to build my career the way I wanted when I started out!
cons: In a right to work state it was pretty nerve wracking to be a contracted employee with the possibility of being hired full time after 6 months.
